Recettear is essentially two games rolled into one, and neither is particularly deep, though the store management aspect is still pretty fleshed out. What it does, it does well (minus a few gripes) but somehow manages to both drag itself out and rush you to the 'end' of the game. The problem with the end-game is that, while it has plenty to offer, it arbitrarily bars you from it with unnecessarily padded goals.  So the shop sim is the meat of the game. There's no point detailing the mechanics, so I'll just point out the failings and oversights I didn't care for.  Patrons have a finite amount of money when they enter the store. This value is influenced by how much they 'like' you, or what 'patron level' they are. The maximum amount of money they have when entering your store is a very important number and it is also  completely invisible  to the player. So when a patron says 'I don't have that much money!' there's no option to say 'Well how much do you have?'  Buying items: some patrons will sell YOU things. You have no option to politely decline; you either make a reasonable offer for something you may or may not want, or you make a terrible offer and ♥♥♥♥ them off. Patrons also have their own dialog style, and occasionally it is unclear whether you're buying an item from them or selling an item to them.  The goal is to do a capitalism until you pay off all your debts. This happens rather rapidly and they kind of rush you through this section of the game so that your time limit is over and you can go at your own pace. This is particularly good for the dungeon-crawling portion of the game, as entering a dungeon will consume most of an entire day and leaves little opportunity for vending.  The dungeon crawling plays very smoothly and each of the playable characters has enough uniqueness to their playstyle to give them all a wholly different feel. There's a considerable number of dungeon and environments. And they're all the same randomly-generated box rooms and hallways given fresh paint at regular intervals. After a short while, it gets stale, and as much as I enjoyed the gameplay, I did not feel compelled to complete even the Obsidian Tower. They just don't keep it fresh or interesting, and that kind of killed the game for me. There's lots of end game content and no motivation or reason to experience it.  All said, I'd still recommend the game if you can nab it for a few bucks because the first 5 to 10 hours are a pretty fun ride.

In most RPG settings you clear out dungeons, then go and sell the unwanted items to shopkeepers. In Recettear, however, you are the shopkeeper. Forced into opening a shop by a loan shark fairy to pay off your father's huge adventuring debts, you need to pay off increasingly huge installments each week or lose your home as collateral.  The game starts of simple enough, but as you progress the game will introduce new features, such as customers placing orders for you to fulfil later, and market fluctuations that will allow you to both buy low and sell high, increasing your profits significantly given the right situation. You can even sponsor adventurers to explore dungeons for you, and during these sessions you'll control them as they fight monsters and explore ruins. The main reasons for doing this is to give you ingredients to combine to make better equipment for the shop, and to unlock more adventurers to play as. Some of them will even come to your store and buy better equipment and weapons for themselves, increasing their effectiveness in the optional combat sections of the game. You'll probably even end up giving huge discounts to the adventurers you hire the most just so they'll be powerful and keep coming back for more deals. It's this kind of thing that really adds to the game's charm and helps you care about the side characters as you learn more about them.  The game is actually very forgiving and failure to meet a payment will send you back to the second day with your inventory, adventurer levels and store reputation intact. This makes something that could have been a very frustrating experience stay fun and oddly relaxing, although it is possible to beat the game in a single run if you feel up for the challenge. Completing the game unlocks the ability to start a new game +, survival mode where you need to pay off increasing amounts of debt each week until it becomes impossible to pay back, or simply carry on where you left off without needing to worry about a deadline each week. Combined with the large amount of items you can discover and create this results in a good replay value, especially for completionists.  As for downsides, the game is bad at explaining itself from the first tutorial. Tear will start the game off by telling you to set the prices for around 130%, but this will actually anger most of the customers and will cause less people to come to your store from the very beginning. You're actually better off selling for 106% - 112% until the public start liking you more, causing the shoppers to eventually warm up to buying the later and more expensive objects you can unlock, and raising your combo to speed up leveling. Neither the level combo nor town reputation are mentioned in the tutorials, which is strange considering they're actually very important to succeeding at the game and it can be frustrating until you realize they are both major factors in your progress.  The dungeon exploration is also very repetitive after a while, but is necessary in order to unlock more of the side stories and characters to come to your store. Since merchant levels are more important to success than your adventurers' combat levels you'll probably ignore the dungeons after a certain amount of time to play the markets, especially after you unlock items in the market that make the payouts from these sessions seem small in comparison.  If you're looking for an original take on the traditional JRPG setting and like the idea of running a store in a fantasy realm then I'd strongly recommend picking Recettear up.

Recettear is very much a delightful game that will keep you entertained for roughly 10 hours depending on how you play (for one play through). The game revolves around running an item shop, and the challenges that brings. For completionists, the main goal is to complete the item encyclopedia, which seems simple enough...however, even after a playthrough of the story mode, you may only be left with <25% completion, especially if you never went through the dungeon. You may have also missed many cutscenes, and missed several potential unlocks. Luckily, the game provides an endless mode for you to clean up any loose ends, and start going towards that 100%!  Pros -cute art style  -Dialogue is well-written, with many subtle jokes and references you may not get your first way through.  -Recette and Tear are a very likeable pair, and they all have unique reactions to other characters.  -Surprising amount of depth, with dungeoneering, crafting, and a small meta game of equipping your adventurers with the best gear.  -Simple, yet effective game mechanics  -Soundtrack is nice  -Offers a fair amount of post-story content, including an endless mode (continue playing without having to worry about debts), New Game+ (With new content. Cons -Art style, especially in dungeons, can be inconsistent. Some mobs are 3d, while your player characters are always 2d sprites.  -Game will either be extremely easy to get through, or RNG will doom you into a situation where you are failing to pay off your debts  -You don't need to do any dungeon'ing or crafting to complete story mode  -Time management can be a bit troublesome, since going through dungeons requires you to give up almost an entire day in your schedule.  -Small frustrating issues, such as being unable to see outstanding orders without speaking to Tear in the shop. (If you leave to go purchase wares, you lose a share of time, and you can only double check what items you need by returning and wasting another share.)  -Dungeon combat is pretty simple, and can be very grindy   Neutral  -Game lies to you, and fails to tell you about important game mechanics. (do NOT sell for 130% base price)  -Why are you selling knives to children...?  -New Game+ is incredibly easy. The amount you must pay never increases.    Overall I actually really like Recettear. It's cute, enjoyable, and can certainly be stressful sometimes. There are a few issues, such as major game mechanics being more risk than reward during the story mode. Still, I would recommend this game not only because it provides for a surprisingly absent genre of game (running an RPG store), but it provides it in such a way that is very appealing and cheerful.

There's already a slew of other reviews telling you this is a good game. They probably either focus a lot or not enough about the sum of all parts. I'm going to only explain why I personally think this game turns from good into great.  Dungeon crawling is considered awful and/or boring for most people I know. They like shooters or some sports games. A few actually like RPGs. And Recettear is definitely a good RPG with a fair amount of simplistic dungeon crawling. It's also interesting how its simplicity aids the game's concept, because if you're anything like me you'll actually like more the character's shop management than going into dungeons to sell the crap out of what a monster unwittingly thought was fun to be lugging around for no reason.  In other words, I think the whole shop management deal is what makes Recettear a good game. If I were to judge it solely on the dungeon crawler aspect I'd tell you that I've played many considerably better dungeon crawlers. Heck, I'd even tell you that Rogue and a great part of it's infinite spawn of clones and wannabes is a better game on dungeon crawling alone. But the shop management, from what goods you'll display on that particular day, the kind of display furniture you're using, and even the little feeling of having sold the junk that some monster considered valuable enough to carry for astronomical values to the masses of curious customers... is only 14.99 away from you.  Let me sweeten the deal here. Carpe Fulgur, the publisher, is one of those that normally has its games featured on discounts on Steam. It's not uncommon to drop around 60% of the price from time to time. And you can't say that the cute-as-kittens-and-fun-as-(games I suppose?) protagonist and its struggles don't capture your heart to the point where you will want to help her get the funds for the next loan she NEEDS to pay, and then see the story evolve gradually with the other characters she gets involved with.  Also, you get to see the witty translation of whatever the original game had in its original language of (I assume) Japanese into 'Capitalism, HO!', Recette's happy money-making battlecry, among other instant classics. There's plenty of humour to read in the dialogues, and sometimes you'll think that you're also paying for a comic book with all of the grins, smiles and even laughter that you'll find yourself performing. Do you still think 14,99 is too much?  There's also a demo for the unbelieving masses to try. That's, of course, the safe approach. Try that demo and you'll see you'll want to buy the full game. If you're worried about the investment, wait for the sales, often Midweek on Steam, or maybe even the big summer or winter sales. You can thank yourself for the investment later.

Recettear: An Item Shop’s Tale, or Recettear for short, is a very intriguing time/money management game with some interesting mechanics to boot. Essentially, you play as Recettear, a young woman living alone in a home that apparently has a huge mortgage on it. Your father took out the mortgage (or loan, whatever) but has yet to pay it back – and he mysteriously vanished! Yeah I didn’t really get that and could have probably thought of a better back-story myself, but hey, it doesn’t really matter!  A fairy comes to pay you a visit one day to take the home away from you (Hey I thought Fairies were nice?!) because the loan is outstanding, but then takes pity on you (Oh right, yep, Fairies are nice) and develops a plan for you to pay back the loan – Turn your downstairs into an Item Shop. Apparently you live in unnamed (Maybe it has a name and I missed it) RPG village where all manner of NPC characters live! How convenient! The intention is to buy cheap goods from the local Guild Master or market, when things are on sale, and resell them at your Item Shop for a markup. Using these funds you’ll of course buy more and buy and sell more and more. An endless circle of buy low, sell high.  But wait, there’s more! Should you be so inclined, the RPG village also has a dungeon! Should you choose to enter the dungeon, you’ll take an adventurer with you (And you’ll unlock more as you play the game) to slay monsters and descend deeper into the depths of the dungeon. Essentially you’ll get free items from killing the baddies, assuming you make it out alive. The dungeon is a very neat feature, and you need to use it in order to unlock more parts of the story line or other adventurers – however I found myself not using it because I could make a much greater profit from buying cheap goods and reselling them normally. You would think that getting something for free and reselling it would be better, but in my experience, I was getting rather junky items even when I went further down the dungeon in any later play through. Also it doesn’t help that it uses 2 pieces of the “daily pie” so to speak (A day is not endless. Going to market, opening the store, adventuring the dungeon or progressing the story takes a portion of the day) and also I really sucked at it. I am a video game pro, but found myself frustrated at the difficulty of some of the boss battles at times. But hey, that’s the challenge and charm of Recettear!  So as you earn money, at the end of each week, you have to pay back a portion of the loan. It starts out small, but then becomes exponentially larger! Week one you may have to pay back 40,000 (Not exact figures, pulling from memory right now…) and week four you find yourself needing 1,200,000! Say WHAT!? It’s achievable… …once you play through another time! If you fail to make a loan payment, the game ENDS! Game over, done, finished, ka put. However, not all is lost! You may get to start the game over from day 1, but you get to keep all the items you have in stock. So when you lose the game, you somehow go back in time (Not really, just my way of thinking how this works…) and have a huge stock of expensive items that you wouldn’t have had on your first play through. It took me three game overs before I was able to make all the loan payments and finish the game. I think it’s a very nice addition to the game, a handicap if you will – if you lose, not all is lost and you can try again with a little help.  Overall, Recettear has an extremely cute (I can’t believe I used the word ‘cute’…) visual appeal and has a great sound and music score included. The story line is interesting to say the least (Some of the dungeon adventurers are odd, but hey, that’s part of the charm!) and has lots of replay ability (Not just replaying when you lose, but once you win you can continue to play and unlock more items and upgrade your store to be better yet!). Overall great game, well worth a play through if you’re interested in JRPG’ish style stories and business sense.

Another time, I bought a beef bowl off of a woman who 'found it in her attic'... and then promptly resold it at a significant mark-up. I'm sure it was tasty...   I'd recommend this game to someone just off of those experiences, but if you want a more traditional review:  Recetter is a combination time-management game and Zelda-esque dungeon crawler. Both halves of the game start out seeming pretty simple, but there is surprising depth to be found in each--making the overall experience a unique and enjoyable one.  You start off with a large debt to pay off, and a fairy companion who suggests you do so by turning your house into an item shop that serves the numerous adventurers in town.  There are three ways to earn the necessary money to pay off your debt:  1) Buy items at the local merchant guild or market and sell them off 2) Hire an adventurer to take you into dungeons to find treasure. 3) Use the various monster parts picked up in the dungeon to craft expensive items  The more time spent selling, the better a merchant you become, and the more higher quality goods you can buy from the market and merchants guild. Conversely, the more time spent adventuring, the more different adventurers you will meet and unlock, the better gear you will find, and the more powerful weapons and armor you can craft (either to sell, or to give to your adventurers to make the next dungeon run easier).  The limiting reagent here is time. You only have so many turns to sell items in your shop or to adventure out into dungeons. Use your time well, and you'll pay off your debt... at which point you can keep going, to meet new adventurers, see new dungeons, craft new materials, and try to make obscene profits.  It's an addictive game with fun, cutey graphics, a great sense of humor, and a lot of interesting (and important) choices to make. And that's besides, the whole sailor-suit incident. What more could you possibly want in a game?

Ever played an RPG, walked into a store and asked yourself what it's like on the other side of the counter? Here's the answer.   I bought Recettear: An Item Shops Tale some time ago and had great fun with it. I downloaded the demo first, because the description and cute art caught my eye and I was curious what to expect from the game. I was amazed and bought the game. Since then, Recettear has grown one of my favorite games of all time.  The story of the game is that a little Girl called Recette Lemongrass wakes up one morning in all kinds of trouble. Her father is long gone and now a fairy tells her, that he left her all his dept, which she has to pay off or her house will be taken.  The game offers you a good combination of two different modes to play. The first one is the shop managing, where you play as Recette, who has turned her house into an item shop in order to be able to pay back her fathers dept. The game lets you do that at weekly rates, that increase every week. So to pay them you have to buy and sell items to the local people and adventurers. This sounds easier than it actually is because you have to pay attention to factors that influence the customers willingness to buy stuff. That is mainly the price, which you can set for each item individually, once a customer wants to buy it. With every successful sale, your skill as a merchant increases, opening new possibilities for you to explore.  Speaking of exploring, there is another mode in this game. That is the exploration of dungeons. Recette can either buy her stock at the market or merchants guild, but she can also hire an adventurer to go into one of the many dungeons to loot it. There are 8 adventurers at your disposal each with his/her own way of fighting and set of skills. Thanks to the easy controls, it is not hard to master them. The dungeons on the other hand can be tricky at first. They are randomly generated and you can't leave whenever you want to. But it is great fun to explore and loot and slay monsters. The bosses are challenging enough to keep things interesting, even if you complete a dungeon for the second or third time (the bosses don't change even if the rest of the stages do).  So the game might appear cute and relaxed, and in some cases it is, but it is also complex and challenging. It may not be a perfect game but with its fun gameplay, good story, nice characters, easy controls and cute graphics, this game is definitely worth a try.

Certain businesses are only open during certain times of day, or on certain days.  - The activity the player will likely spend the most time doing is running the shop - which includes stocking your shop, tending to customers, haggling, ticking off scam artists, and making a profit. - The player can go to the town and buy supplies from the Market or the Merchant's Guild. - The player can interact with various characters during random events, which will generally increase their liking of you and may earn you a new customer or adventurer. - You can hire an adventurer from the Adventurer's Guild to go into a dungeon and gather loot for you. During this time, you control the adventurer and must fight enemies, avoid traps, and find lots of treasure (or be incapacitated trying).  There's more to the game then just these previous activities, but that's for you to find out for your own. When/If you beat the game, you unlock a few new game modes, such as  - Endless, where you can continue to play your game endlessly without worrying about payments - New Game+ where you start over with your current items and Merchant Level - Survival Mode where you start over and your debt never ends, but constantly increases and you have to play until the debt overwhelms you and you lose your home!  Err... Aaaanyway, I recommend this game. It's fun... also...Capitalism, Ho!
